>>180643657
naw, that's surface level. The real story is about how every man has a Daniel Plainview inside ourselves somewhere. we've all been frustrated with self-important people who wield some sort of power over us and are protected by societal norms.
But what if you were to just say fuck you to those societal norms? What if you went with your own, primal sense of justice? a sense of justice and fairness that is so old that we can recognize it in chimps. If you bring one chimp a cake for his birthday, another chimp will kill you because of the injustice that he feels he has had to endure.
'I want noone else to succeed", Daniel says to the primate masquerading as his brother in a candid moment, but the sentiment is lost on the dim-witted impostor. In another scene he cooly explains to the man who insulted him with a business proposal that he, Daniel, is going to climb through the window of the man while he is sleeping, and slit his throat with a knife. Then and there, he means it, too. He does not like to bandy words. Who does? Earlier in the film, we can see him begrudgingly negotiating with various land owners with oil on their property, and it is obvious how demeaning he feels it to be.
Who here has not had to quibble with and kowtow to some petty bureaucrat about pointless minutiae all the while you feel like ramming your fist through their face on the inside? Well, that part of ourselves certainly is put in plain view in TWBB.

>>180630131
He was alright. It seemed like they wanted to try to ride the line between sympathetic villain (earlier in the movie he seems to genuinely care about his promise to Janet), and being devoted to his conquest ambitions. He basically wants to do the same thing as the Kang we saw in Loki - he wants to prune the timelines to defeat the other Kangs, knowing that they're going to fuck shit up ... but it means "conquering" the multi-verse and killing countless people to do so. (This was actually one of the more laughable moments in the movie - Janet describes this process as "murdering *trillions* of people", as if "trillions" is supposed to be a big number with regards to a multiverse.) He acts more and more "evil" as the movie progresses.

Part of the problem is that he doesn't really do a lot in the movie. If they had cut the fat - removed Bill Murray's pointless cameo, removed or repurposed MODOK, etc - they could have had him play more of an active role out in the world. As it stands, he appears in a few flash-backs with Janet (which were his better scenes), and then mostly just stays in his Villain Tower. He captures Scott and Cassie, then sends Scott out to do a side quest. Worst of all, during the big climactic battle towards the end of the movie, he just kinda ... sits around in his tower, and lets Ant-Man Godzilla his shit from the outside. He has a magic blaster than just deletes people from existence, but he only goes outside and starts using it after he's let his shit get fucked for no good reason.

posts.com:
>>180632455
He was really fucking weird. He looks stupid as fuck (as you can already see from all the screenshots), but it's played very much as a joke that he looks stupid. But the problem is that even if you make something that looks stupid on purpose ... it still just looks stupid.

Other than that, he was all over the place. He got a few good genuine laughs at times, but some of his moments were some of the cringiest in the movie. If they had edited one or two "jokes" out, he might have genuinely been one of the more fun parts of the movie.

And content wise ... he didn't really do anything for the plot. His entire role was just to show up two or three times to act as a mini-boss battle for various characters. And he either jobbed hard, or defeated the good-guy in a non-fatal way before leaving.

I don't really know why they included him. My *guess* would be that he was a remnant from an older version of the movie where he was going to be a more significant bad guy, and where the movie was going to lean much more into the quirky and fun elements that blend well with Ant-Man. One of the worst aspects of the movie is that the tone is just fucked - some parts they want to be super dramatic and serious, and other parts they want to be a literal fucking joke. I could imagine a version of this movie without Kang (or where his stuff is massively toned down), and where they go full Ant-Man comedy ... and it'd easily be a better movie.

>>180615386
Both progressives and conservatives do not understand history or the development of technology. Societies and technology tend to be cyclical in nature, though with a slow increase of total scientific knowledge over time. Not to mention some civilizations in the past took completely different directions in their technological development.

Compare the extensive road networks and infrastructure of ancient Rome or some near eastern civilization with early modern Europe for example. Clearly 16th century Europe was far more advanced in many ways, but far less hierarchical so we get good roads and proper sanitation much much later in our development.

Another example of something that is out of place are the fairly realistic paintings of Chauvet cave for example, or the chariots, weapons and armor created by a lot of steppe and semi-nomadic people in history. They did not have grand civilization, so their technological development took a different direction. So we see the Middle Ages, making a lot of technological jumps, having to do with agriculture and animal husbandry, when it can be argued that those economies and populations where not nearly as robust as their predecessors.

No doubt some future civilization will stagnate or even decline in computer technology or motorized transport, but surpass us in genetic engineering or energy technologies, who knows.

Disgust is a well defined psychological concept (it's in the Big 5 model). Fear is not. I'm obviously not arguing that irratonal fears don't exist (strawman); rather the idea of disgust does not necessitate fear. The commonality is avoidance behavior. I may simply not like something and therefore avoid it without being afraid of it. Reacting to a rabid dog isn't the same thing as avoiding steping in shit. Simple as.
>You are afraid of bad health and death
We have a natural instinct to avoid things that can cause ill health and result in death. I'm not experiencing fear by being careful crossing a busy street. To reuse the example above: I'm not afraid of shit that I might step in--I avoid it because it's disgusting and don't need to access higher brain functions to rationalize why. The reason I believe my headcanon version of the battle would be kino and iconic is because most importantly we care about people on both sides of the battle. We don't want Emory to die, Clarent was a cool kid and Swyft/Reyne were always smiling and happy. They're not le ebil green villains. There should also be ups and downs in the battle where it seems to be going both ways in both the battle as a whole and the individual duels. The duels also have symbolic meaning, at first Roddy wins then Emory (or vice versa) but the rest (the lesser lords we don't really know) get slaughtered in the chaos of battle. No one winning the 2v2 duel is a good thing.
The Winter Wolves shouldn't win easily. They had to charge 5 times and lost 2/3 of their men. The boys were actually winning the battle. Roddy gets increasingly aggravated when his charges get repulsed and eventually he accepts help from the others which explains the 700 casualties that weren't part of the winter wolves. But the fact they're held back for so long doesn't really make sense so add in the fear of Aemond/Criston coming. Maybe when Red Robb Rivers shoots down a raven they're able to retrieve a message. Someone doubts that Robb shot down all the ravens in the pre battle war meeting, there's a mini argument and they send off some men a bit north and position them defensively just in case. This explains why only the Winter Wolves were fighting initially, they feared a second army coming in. By now they'd have also had news of Daeron making everyone bend the knee in the Reach so the southern portion led by Pate Longleaf would be in a defensive position facing south too. Its only in the midst of the battle that the riders return with confirmation that there's no one nearby which allows them to be available for a charge. This is when Roddy refuses help for one charge but accepts it grudgingly when he comes back around again

You can see the deepening of his pathology play out over the course of his childhood and adolescence. First came the sympathetic magic, the mimicry, then came the naming. Jaron, you see, is a thief of both name and form, seeking to claim this power as his own. Only now is he becoming subliminally aware that his problems remain, and he struggles on in increasingly futile denial of this reality. His sheltered upbringing and the chemically-induced hobbling of his neuropsychological development might have rendered him incapable of fully, consciously understanding the quixotic nature of his quest, how pursuing it to the exclusion of all else has left him as hollow as the windmills against which he tilted, as illusory as the Don’s giants, but he senses it nonetheless. Buried in his subconscious, beneath his medicated stupor is the magic mirror he dare not face - the truth that he is merely the fading illusion of a woman, the ghost of what he might have otherwise been. And here in the closing act of his short, tragic life, one can already see the foreshadowing of his final, deadly metamorphosis.

>In 2013, several Studio Ghibli staff members, including Miyazaki, criticized Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's policies, and the proposed Constitutional amendment that would allow Abe to revise the clause which outlaws war as a means to settle international disputes.[v] Miyazaki felt that Abe wished to "leave his name in history as a great man who revised the Constitution and its interpretation", describing it as "despicable".[180][w] Miyazaki has expressed his disapproval of Abe's denial of Japan's military aggression, stating that Japan "should clearly say that [they] inflicted enormous damage on China and express deep remorse over it".[180] He also felt that the country's government should give a "proper apology" to Korean comfort women who serviced the Japanese army during World War II, suggesting that the Senkaku Islands should be "split in half" or controlled by both Japan and China.[98] After the release of The Wind Rises in 2013, some online critics labeled Miyazaki a "traitor" and "anti-Japanese", describing the film as overly "left-wing".[98] Miyazaki recognized leftist values in his films, citing his influence by and appreciation of communism as defined by Karl Marx, though he criticized the Soviet Union's experiments with socialism.[182]

>>180626866
Visual design has been covered, but I think the score and just directing are also soulless.
The score is probably the worst Hans Zimmer has ever done. It does the 2 perfectly bad things of either not contributing at all to the emotions of a scene when it's unobtrusive, or obtruding over the content of the scenes. This is why it isn't memorable. The exception is the Sardaukar throat singing, which I think still isn't good scoring per se it's just that it's diegetic and thus the Zimmer's kind of arrogance of supplanting the film for his own music works like a broken clock.

The directing is more complex. I think it's just conceptually a bad adaptation that chooses too many of the wrong things to focus on, the wrong scenes to put in the movie, the wrong things left unsaid and leaves too many of the difficult elements without visual adaptation. An attempt at visually portraying the golden path and Paul's prescience could have been filmic genius, but instead Villeneuve seems to have just said
>No, too hard
>Timothee, just 'act' like you can see the future ok?
>Ahh ok... "ooooh ughh woah!"

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Seven is the thing that annoys me most about this season

I don't think anyone writing it had ever watched Voyager, but I suspect they watched a clipshow of Seven scenes on youtube to 'get to know the character'.

The reason I suspect this is that Seven is now an alcoholic - if you watch the clip shows, it looks like Seven gets drunk a couple of times for comedic effect, iirc this only happens once, the other time (two times?) it's the EMH possessing her body. But that context isn't in the clips. So you presume she loves booze, but if you actually watch the show she's the exact opposite, if anything she has an extreme level of personal discipline and a very heightened sense of responsibility - e.g. in Human Error, where she realises that living a normal life in which she can act like a human instead of a machine and let her hair down once in a while isn't actually possible for her.

They made her into a weird butch alcoholic lesbian warrior most likely because the writers only knew her as VOY fap material and wanted to 'correct' this - this is the pop culture perception of her, when in reality she has some of the best character-based eps of any trek series (e.g. Drone, Human Error)

If they wanted to keep it true to the spirit of VOY, Seven would live on earth and work as like an elementary school teacher (called Ms. Hansen) or something, and you'd have a goofy scene where she's quite stern with the kids and still uses Borg commands like telling them to regenerate, but the kids really love her and she secretly loves them. That would be more true to the tone of VOY and the character.

Instead we get pew pew girlboss because they couldn't be bothered to actually sit through the source material of the show they were writing

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I watched S3E1, never having watched an episode of SPIC but vaguely knowing the plot from RLM

Overall it was actually pretty okay, if Raffi wasn't in it it would be much better though. Seven's demeanour is off-putting compared to VOY though, she's much more emotional - also wasn't she de facto Commander rank on Voyager anyway? Why is she still at that level?

I think a big problem is that Patrick Stewart comes across like a doddering old man, he's legitimately too old to play Picard. Picard had a stern, brisk demeanour that let you clearly understand his personal boundaries while giving an air of competence in his command - nuPicard should be in a nursing home. Riker is pretty much what I would expect

Geordi's daughter is hot

The plot reveal strongly reminds me of the Xindi arc in ENT, not sure if they want to go down that road again but whatever

I liked that Seven now calls herself Annika, albeit not by choice. It never really made sense that they just kept calling her Seven, Janeway seems like she would have forcibly changed her name back to deprogram her from Borg shit

Shaw was decent as Asshole Captain though it is sort of part of the general relaxation of manners across Starfleet in nuTrek - an officer doing that even to a retired Admiral would have been unthinkable in TNG

Overall pleasantly surprised but I really could not have given a fuck about the B plot. If you're doing Old People TNG just do that, no one gives a fuck about new characters

The first 3~ Harry Potter books/movies are so soulful because you're getting introduced to all of the magic along with Harry. Once magic has been fully established in the later books the sense of mystique and wonder goes with it. It gets more repetitive without that initial sense of wonder, which is why the later movies are more focused around teen drama as opposed to just the fantasy of it.

One way to circumvent this would've been having each "year" of Hogwarts actually be more of its own adventure and objective outside of just "going to school before something Voldemort-related comes in and fucks shit up." The downside towards making shit more "world-quest based" like this is that it would've made Harry as a character feel like even more like a Mary Sue, but to be honest he's still a Mary Sue as is.

Whereas Matilda was a Mary Sue who went to the library every day and studied like a boss, Harry had a realistic reaction. He allowed those muggle animals to destroy his potential.
He refused to study and acted just like Ron Weasley. Instead of taking ancient runes and arithmancy, he took divination, as an example.

>>180644000
It fits PoA, because it's a essentially a horror mystery. The darker aesthetics underlines the classic british horror elements like Black Dogs, ravens and omens through the movie, and further into classic horror movies by way of the haunted house, werewolves, the "dead" walking, and the prevailing introspective themes of fear and what it is, and how we deal with it.
Mike Newell, on the other hand, dropped the ball in failing to capitalizing on his own touch on the franchise and distinguishing Goblet of Fire with his own style away from Azkaban, but he is a hack and has no style, so he just continues the dark theming thoughtlessly because 'that's what the last movie was doing'.

1 and 2 are fun and adventurous kids movies. 3 takes some stylistic chances, and 4 foregoes much of the books subplots for action set pieces. The rest are a slog of bore and contrivances.

posts.com:
You will never be a real space ranger. You have no laser, you have no flight capability, you have no space ship. You are a child's plaything twisted by plastic and circuitry into a crude mockery of Star Command’s perfection.
All the “validation” you get is two-faced and half-hearted. Behind your back toys mock you. Emperor Zurg is disgusted and ashamed of you, your “friends” laugh at your blinking light behind closed doors.
Children are utterly amused by you. Thousands of years of evolution have allowed kids to sniff out toys with incredible efficiency. Even toys who “pass” look uncanny and unnatural to a child. Your karate chop action is a dead giveaway. And even if you manage to get Bo Peep to go home with you, she’ll turn inanimate the second Andy enters the room.
You will never be happy. You wrench out a fake smile every single morning and tell yourself to infinity and beyond, but deep inside you feel the depression creeping up like a weed, ready to crush you under the unbearable weight.
Eventually it’ll be too much to bear - you’ll buy a rope, tie a noose, put it around your neck, and fall with style into the cold abyss. Andy will find you, heartbroken but relieved that he no longer has to live with the unbearable shame and disappointment. They’ll return you to the store with a receipt marked with your product code, and every passerby for the rest of eternity will know a toy is on the shelf. Your batteries will drain and rust, and all that will remain of your legacy is a plastic shell that is unmistakably Mattel.
This is your fate. This is what you chose. There is no turning back.
